div.p: Abstract-This paper describes two different applications of wavelet transforms in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In each case, the use of wavelets offers tangible benefits over the traditional Fourier transform based imaging. These stem from the simultaneous time and frequency localization properties of the wavelets.

The first application utilizes the localization properties of wavelets to acquire single T, weighted images in times which are short relative to current methods. An interesting combinatorial scheduling problem arises from the multiscale structure inherent in the formulation of this procedure. Its solution is sketched and applied to the imaging process.

The second example is a technique for potentially "instant" imaging. Image acquisition is modeled as an inverse wavelet transform of the spin density in the region in question. Signal acquisition takes place in as few as one or two echoes after the excitation by radio frequency (RF) pulses designed to excite a moving band of spins in a slice. These sweeping RF pulses excite strips of spins which rephase at different times during acquisition. They replace phase-encoding gradients; no fast pulsed gradients are required as in echo planar imaging, which is the "instant" imaging technique presently being developed by MR researchers.
Some applications of these techniques in medical imaging are described, with specific examples presented by means of simulations. Comparisons with corresponding traditional methods are given.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION AGNETIC resonance imaging (MRI) has become an
div.p: M essential part of diagnostic radiology in the last ten years. MRI, like ultrasound and x-ray computed tomography (CT), is used to generate two-dimensional images of sections of the body. MRI stands out from these other methods in at least two important regards: the sections imaged can have arbitrary orientation and position and the contrast between soft tissues is large. MRI is limited only by its spatial resolution and long imaging times.

The inherent flexibility of MRI also permits its application in many clinical tasks other than imaging static anatomy. Important recent applications include imaging blood vessels without contrast agents [12], [13], [33], [42], measuring diffusion in tissue [43], [5 I], measuring tissue temperature [3 11, cardiac imaging [23], [32], [45], and dynamic imaging of the musculoskeletal system [ 171, [46].

There are many techniques used to obtain MR images, but all involve excitation by radio frequency, (RF), magnetic fields of the nuclear magnetic spins in a sample of interest. The precession of these spins in a carefully controlled magnetic field causes the sample to echo back with a composite electromagnetic signal whose analysis can reveal the types and positions of the nuclei within the sample. Almost all of the various approaches to MRI [6] employ variants of the Fourier methods to meet the signal processing requirements.
Here we survey our recent work on the application of wavelet transforms in two types of imaging [52], 1221: two-dimensional Fourier transform spin echo imaging, and fast imaging.

Two-dimensional Fourier transform, spin echo imaging is by far the most common clinical scanning technique. In this type of imaging, imaging speeds are limited by the intrinsic relaxation times of the spins. We are using the localized support properties of wavelets to minimize the number of times each group of spins must be excited and allowed to relax, thereby minimizing imaging time. The localization properties of wavelets also limit motion artifacts and Gibbs ringing, which are serious problems in MRI.

There is also a large research effort devoted to so-called instant imaging techniques in MRI. This is motivated by the desire to image moving structures such as the heart and the abdomen [l], [21], [34], [37], 1401, [451, [441, [50]. The most prominent technique is called echo planar imaging. This can provide an image of a single slice within a single echo in as little as 40 ms [49]. We are attempting to approach this level of performance with a new technique using coherent state transforms, namely windowed Fourier and wavelet transforms. The goal is the compression of the MR output signal, so that an image can be quickly obtained in a few echoes, without the use of the fast switched gradients which are required by the echo planar technique.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. We begin with a brief overview of magnetic resonance imaging. The particular goal of this section is the description of some of the unique signal processing issues in MRI which may benefit from the introduction of wavelet and other coherent state transforms. The next section describes the significant improvements deriving from a straightforward application of orthogonal wavelets to a particular spin-echo imaging problem. This involves the careful scheduling of the excitations of localized bands of spins living within dyadic intervals over a range of scales. This scheduling problem is described and its solution sketched. From this, we turn to a section describing a completely different application of phase space transforms to the problem of "instant" imaging in MR. In particular, we describe a technique in which the signal acquisition 0018-9448/92$03,00 0 1992 IEEE process may be modeled as an inverse wavelet or windowed Fourier transform. The sweeping RF pulses which implement this are described and simulated. We present some of the details of implementation on an MR scanner, including timing sequences and an analysis of the speed of this process. Finally, conclusions are presented.

div.head: MRI FUNDAMENTALS
div.p: As stated before, MRI is a relatively new noninvasive imaging technique which complements older methods including ultrasound and X-ray computed tomography (CT). Basic references describing these techniques abound [27], [391, [48]; here we try to give enough insight into the techniques to permit an appreciation of the signal processing issues which benefit from coherent state signal processing.
MRI has carved out an important niche in medical imaging. Some perspective of its applicability is gained by a comparison with alternatives like ultrasound and CT.

Ultrasound is inexpensive and is done in real time. However, ultrasound cannot be used for structures that are deep in the body or where there is air or bone around the structure of interest. Therefore, with few exceptions, ultrasound is only viable in the abdomen and heart.

X-ray CT techniques offer excellent spatial resolution, but have very limited soft tissue contrast. Contrast in CT is determined by the electron density and the effective atomic number of the materials imaged. Bone is the only tissue in the body with dramatically different electron density or effective atomic number; soft tissues generally have very similar electron densities and atomic numbers.

MRI contrast, on the other hand, is determined by the relaxation parameters of the water in tissue; the intrinsic contrast between soft tissues in MRI is many times what it is for CT. For example, the white matter of the brain has 12% lower CT number than the gray matter [4], while white matter has a 140% higher signal than gray matter in an MRI examination [l 1). MRI is limited only by its spatial resolution properties and long imaging times.

div.head: A . Nuclear Magnetic Spin
div.p: A nucleus with an unpaired nucleon has intrinsic spin. The nuclei of hydrogen, phosphorous, and sodium atoms all have observable spins. Almost all MRI uses the hydrogen nuclei of a sample to construct an image.

In an MR scanner, a large, external, static magnetic field, H,, causes alignment of the nuclear spins in a sample; the vector sum can be approximated by the bulk magnetization vector of the sample, M . The bulk magnetization precesses around the external field just as a top precesses around the gravitational field. The frequency of precession, f,,,,, , is proportional to the size of the static magnetic field and is called the Larmor frequency:

The constant of proportionality, y, is different for each nucleus; it is 42 MHz/Tesla for hydrogen. Many things contribute to the magnetic field felt by the spins, including the static magnetic field. Another influence is the fields of atoms adjzcent to the spins, which causes a slight variation in the Larmor frequency called a chemical shift. For example, in imaging tissues, one finds a chemical shift between protons in water, which are bonded to oxygen, and protons in fat which are bonded to carbon.

The effect of electromagnetic fields on nuclear spins requires a quantum mechanical description. However, MR can be described approximately with a classical treatment of the magnetization and the forces on it. This approximation is sufficient in part because the effects of many nuclei are summed to form the bulk magnetization, which is the actual observable property of the sample. The magnetization in H , can be described exactly like a spinning top in a gravitational field.

The Larmor frequency can be varied by changing the magnetic field experienced by the spins contributing to the bulk magnetization. In a MR scanner, the magnetic field in the sample is varied from Ho by the addition of three switched, linear magnetic field gradients: one in each orthogonal direction in space. These magnetic field gradients are used to determine which portion of the signal comes from each part of the image, as discussed in detail a bit later. Before turning to imaging considerations, we must first discuss the properties of a single group of spins.

div.head: B. Magnetic Resonance
div.p: The net magnetization can be pushed out of alignment with the static, external magnetic field, H,, by means of another external magnetic field that is rotating with the magnetization at the Larmor frequency. The effect of a field rotating at any frequency other than f,,,,, cancels when averaged over many cycles. Thus, only a field rotating at the Larmor frequency has a net effect; this is a classical explanation of resonance.
A rotating magnetic field is created in the plane perpendicular to H , by applying a pulsed radio frequency (RF)

voltage across a specially designed coil surrounding the sample. At the end of such an excitation, the magnetization vector of the sample precesses around the static magnetic field at an angle which is proportional to the product of the strength of the RF field and the length of time for which it was applied. RF pulses are characterized by the angle they push the magnetization to, e.g., a 90" pulse pushes the magnetization vector down to the plane perpendicular to the static magnetic field. This is referred to as the transverse plane. The precessing magnetization generates a very small voltage in a pickup coil, which in some machines is the same as the transmitter coil. Since this coil can only detect fields in the transverse plane, the returning voltage is proportional to the projection of the magnetization vector into this plane, as well as to the number of spins which are precessing. The voltage generated oscillates at the Larmor frequency.

The signal generated by the magnetization after an RF pulse is called a free induction decay (FID). As the name implies, the signal decays over time. In an ideal system, there are two types of exponential decay contributing to this; they are characterized by decay constants T , and T,. Spin-spin, or transverse relaxation, occurs fastest and is characterized by T2. It is caused by a loss of coherence among the precessing nuclear spins contributing to the transverse bulk magnetization, and is due to local interactions between spins. As a consequence, the spins begin to contribute to the net magnetization out of phase from one another. This effect continues over time until the signal is canceled or dephased.
T2 is on the order of 50 ms in tissues.

Spin-lattice relaxation, or longitudinal relaxation, is characterized by T,. It is caused by the magnetization realigning itself with the static magnetic field as the spins lose energy to the lattice. In tissues, TI generally varies from 200 to 800 ms; the purer the liquid, the longer TI becomes. For example, cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) is very pure water and has a T, of 5 s. This can be exploited in medical imaging by introducing contrast agents, such as salts, to decrease the TI of tissue in the sample.

Both TI and T2 decay times are characteristic of the tissues themselves. In a real system, there are other sources of dephasing which have nothing to do with tissue properties but which also contribute to the exponential decay of the FID. Anything that causes a change in the Larmor frequency across the sample causes dephasing; inhomogeneity in the static magnetic field, the application of a magnetic field gradient, and chemical shifts all cause some spins to rotate at different Larmor frequencies, causing dephasing. In practice, all of these sources of spin incoherence, including true T2 relaxation, are lumped together and characterized by a time constant T;. In liquids, TI is always much larger than TT so the FID effectively decays with TT.

Now that the basic processes have been outlined, differential equations describing the evolution of the magnetization in this classical picture can be presented. div.head: C. Spin Echoes
div.p: The FID following an RF pulse decays exponentially with decay constant TT. The decay is caused by spin-spin relaxation, which is a property of the tissue, and by all other sources of dephasing, many of which are not properties of the tissue, e.g., static field inhomogeneities. A technique known as spin echoing may be used to eliminate those dephasing effects whose rate of dephasing is constant in time, such as those arising from static field inhomogeneities. A 90" RF pulse puts the magnetization into the transverse plane; the maximum possible signal is obtained initially, but the FID decays away quickly with TT time constant. The signal can be too small to observe after only 5-10 ms. With the spin echo technique, the signal can be recalled with a 180" RF pulse at time T after the 90" pulse. In spin warp imaging, a slice is first determined with a slice-selection RF pulse. A single slice of spins is excited by turning the z gradient on during the RF pulses. When the z gradient is turned on, the Larmor frequency is a linear function of z. An idealized RF pulse is typically a sinc function which is comprised of pure harmonics with amplitude 1 in a certain band, and amplitude 0 outside that band; that is, the Fourier transform or spectral content of the excitation pulse is an indicator or boxcar function supported on a particular interval of frequencies. Only spins with Larmor frequencies corresponding to harmonics present in the RF are excited. Therefore, spins with Larmor frequencies inside the support of the boxcar are excited; spins with Larmor frequencies outside the boxcar are not excited. The result is a slab of excited spins transverse to the z axis, with the depth of the slab corresponding to the support of the Fourier transform of the RF excitation. Only the spins within this slab contribute signal to the image. The width of the slab can be changed by changing either the time constant of the sinc or the gradient strength. The z position of the slab can be changed by changing the center frequency of the RF pulse.

div.head: E. Echo Planar Imaging
div.p: A variation of Fourier imaging called echo planar imaging was reported in 1977 by Mansfield [37]. Echo planar imaging is a method of imaging a single slice in a single echo. The entire matrix in (9) is obtained in a single echo. A great deal of effort has been put into echo planar in order to image the moving heart [16], [401, 1451, [50].
In echo planar, large gradients are used. A large x gradient is used to make the bandwidth of the object imaged, B W , as large as possible,

By maximizing G,, Tline is minimized. When T,ine is much smaller than 4T,*, many lines of the matrix in (9) can be obtained from one echo. The quantity 4T,* is a measure of how long the echo is; recall that the echo rings up exponentially with time constant T: and then rings down exponentially with the same time constant. In conventional 2D Fourier transform imaging, each line of the matrix in (9) takes one echo. On the other hand, in echo planar imaging all of the steps required to image the line must happen many times within one echo. In particular, a phase-encoding gradient pulse must be turned rapidly on and off between the acquisition of each line. The readout gradient must also switch signs between lines of data to keep the phase accumulating correctly. The primary problem with echo planar imaging is that very large, very fast, switched gradients are very hard to build. As a result, data is sampled when T,* decay has reduced the signal dramatically. This reduces signal-to-noise ratio and produces artifacts. More complete treatments can be found elsewhere [39], [40], [50].

div.head: F. Signal-to-Noise
div.p: Some influences on the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) are common to all imaging techniques. The signal in an imaging experiment is proportional to the number of spins contributing to the signal. The signal, therefore, is proportional to the pixel size in the image; the better the resolution gets, the more the SNR suffers. The noise is generally thought to be a 1 / f process. Over the very tight bandwidth sampled, the noise is essentially proportional to the bandwidth [25]; the larger the gradients, the wider the bandwidth and the greater the noise. The signal is also determined by (7); the longer the TR the larger the signal, and the smaller the TE the larger the signal. Imaging effectively is always a tradeoff between these parameters.

div.head: WAVELET ENCODING
div.p: In diagnostic radiology, there are several very common examinations which require three to five T2 weighted slices, e.g., in spinal examinations. A TR of 2.5 s is generally required to reduce T, weighting and a TE of 80 ms is required to get T2 weighting. The minimum TR is roughly 100 ms. Such a sequence takes 256 x 2.5 s or around 1 1 min; normally 20 to 25 slices can be imaged with the sequence. We are developing wavelet encoding to replace phase encoding in these situations. Wavelet encoding uses the local support properties of wavelets to image a single slice with the minimum repetition time and still have an effective repetition time many times greater.

In these schemes, the x dimension is frequency encoded, just as it is in 2D Fourier imaging. However, instead of exciting the entire slice with every RF pulse, as is done in phase encoding, each RF pulse excites a wavelet-shaped profile at a particular scale and position along the y axis in the slice. The echo produced is the inner product of the wavelet-excited profile and the spin distribution along the y axis. Therefore, the wavelet transform of the spin distribution can be measured by using a sequence of RF pulses at the correct dilations and translations. The original distribution of spins along the gradient can be found with the inverse discrete wavelet transform of the signal [8], [35].

Wavelet encoding is similar to a technique which excites profiles in the form of Hadamard functions [6]. However, the wavelet profiles have localized support, in contrast to Hadamard encoding. A particular consequence is that almost all of the excited profiles are zero over most of the encoded interval, so that only a small band of spins is excited by most of the RF pulses. These pulses are arranged so that consecutive excitations drive up spins in disjoint regions of the sample. So although some part of the sample is being excited every TR seconds, any particular spin is left to relax for many TR periods before it is called on again. This increase in the effective repetition time felt by a given spin is accomplished without increasing the overall imaging time. This is extremely useful in some applications, and is in marked contrast to the traditional Fourier and Hadamard approaches to MR. Note that every RF pulse excites all the spins in Fourier transform imaging and in the Hadamard technique.
Therefore, the TR is the same as the effective repetition time.

We shall present wavelet encoding in a technique that produces a projection image. A projection image has no slice selection, so the voxels extend through the object imaged as it does in an x-ray. There are several slice-selection techniques that can be used [ 2 ] , [38]; however it is easier to see the features of wavelet encoding in a simpler projection sequence. The sequence used to produce wavelet-encoded projection images is shown in Fig. 3.

Wavelet encoding has several advantages over phase encoding [52]. First, there is much less ringing caused by partial volume effects in wavelet encoding than in phase encoding. The ringing is an artifact in the reconstructed image associated with the presence of an edge in the original sample. The severity of this is related to the coarseness of resolution, or undersampling, of the discrete reconstruction; dividing the fixed bandwidth of the encoded image into a greater number of pixels reduces the effect. We have found that Gibbs ringing in the Fourier transform is much more severe than the corresponding undersampling effects in wavelet transforms. The most important advantage of wavelet encoding is its immunity to motion artifacts. Motion of the object imaged during phase encoding causes a misregistration of signal. The Fourier transform reconstruction spreads the misregistered signal all the way across the image; the basis functions of the expansion are not local so the effect of the error is not local. This phenomenon will be demonstrated later.

It should be noted that there is at least one previously known method for obtaining large effective repetition times, TR,, with a short TR; namely a method known as line scanning. Instead of exciting a wavelet-shaped excited profile, a line in the image is excited; the image is accumulated one line at a time [15]. However, the signal-to-noise ratio in line scanning is significantly less than that in 2D Fourier imaging precisely because only one line of spins produces signal at any time during this procedure; see, for example, 139, Ch. 51. the spins producing signal at any time. The standard analyses can be applied to wavelet encoding as well; wavelet encoding, as we have implemented it here, has signal-to-noise ratios greater than line scanning and less than 2D Fourier imaging.

To date, we have used the Haar wavelets because there is no overlap between adjacent wavelets at the same scale; this implies each spin must be excited only once for each scale. However, the discontinuities in the Haar functions are difficult to reproduce; RF pulses must be quite long. Therefore, we are starting to use other orthogonal wavelet bases, such as the wavelets of Lemarie/Battle [36] and Daubechies [8].

These wavelets are smoother and reduce the bandwidth requirements on the RF pulse. On the other hand, the overlap of these wavelets at a given scale means that each spin must be excited more times. This cuts into the effective repetition rate TR,, as the number of times the spins must be excited and allowed to decay determines the effective repetition time. This is offset somewhat by an increase in the signal produced. We are also exploring the use of the scaling functions of multiresolution analyses instead of the wavelets for the excited profiles.

div.head: A . The Wavelet Encoding Technique
div.p: A function's wavelet transform is given by the set of inner products of the function with the wavelet at the proper scales and translations. Here, the exponential is a result of the x gradient on during the signal acquisition; the resulting signal for each wavelet scale j and translation k is a function of time during the echo. The x gradient encodes p'( x , y ) in the x direction with frequency; p ' ( x , y ) in the x direction is reconstructed with a Fourier transform of the signal during the echo. Each excitation and echo provides the signal at one scale and translation. The discrete wavelet transform [35] with N points must be sampled at scales j = 0 to j = log, N -1 and at k = 2 / translations at each scale j. One average is also required by the wavelet transform; it is obtained by exciting a boxcar or indicator function over the FOV encoded. Digitizing the signal echoes following the N excitations creates a three-dimensional data matrix: indexed by j , k , and t . The reconstruction is formed by performing a discrete Fourier transform in t and an inverse wavelet transform in j and k . The resulting two-dimensional array is the reconstructed image.
The set of N excitations required by wavelet encoding is the same as the N excitations required by phase encoding.

The difference is that all but two of the excitations in wavelet encoding excite only a part of the FOV. Each spin is excited once for each of the log, N scales and once for the average, i.e., each spin is excited log, N + 1 times. Two of the excitations excite the entire FOV: the average and the largest scale wavelet. The remaining N -2 excitations each only affect a portion of the spins. We now turn to the problem of optimal scheduling of these excitations.

div.head: D. Discussion
div.p: There is a very important benefit of wavelet encoding: motion artifacts are dramatically reduced. Typical motion artifacts in actual phase-encoded MR images can be seen in The ability to generate T2 weighted spin echo images one slice at a time is very useful in the clinical setting. T2 weighted images of the spine are usually generated with the spinal column in the image plane. The spinal column is thin enough to be imaged completely in three to five images. In traditional spin warp imaging, this takes 10 to 11 minutes. If the wavelet encoding can be made slice-selective, the same images could be generated with wavelet encoding in 1.5-3.6 minutes. This is a very significant time savings; a half-hour MR examination generally costs 500 to 1000 dollars or more. We are working on methods of making the projection-imaging schemes we presented into slice-selective imaging schemes.

div.head: IV. FAST MR IMAGING WITH PHASE SPACE TRANSFORMS
div.p: In this section, we describe methods for encoding the spin distribution as an inverse phase space transform. Our initial work in this area utilized the windowed Fourier transform for this purpose. Subsequent modifications of this technique permit the substitution of an orthogonal wavelet transform, which promises certain improvements. Both methods offer specific advantages over Fourier encoding of MR images. Specifically, an entire image may be encoded in a single spin echo, offering the potential to generate very fast MR images. It appears that acquisition times might approach those of echo planar imaging without the use of the fast switched gradients required by that technique. Instead, during data acquisition the readout gradient is constant in the windowed Fourier transform case, or varies smoothly in the wavelet case; the gradient does not switch sign between "lines" of data as it does in echo planar scanning. A possible further advantage may be derived from the fact that the field of view may be restricted as desired. The limitations of the techniques involve the speed with which the spins phase and dephase. These techniques also appear to suffer signal-to-noise disadvantages compared to two-dimensional Fourier encoding. However, they do not suffer from TT decay as echo planar imaging does and do not require small tip angles as FLASH imaging does.

The basic concept of the windowed Fourier transform (WFT) based technique and the wavelet transform (WT) based technique is the same. We must encode the spin density of a two-dimensional slice as a time domain output signal and then recover it. In both methods, one dimension is frequency encoded with a constant magnetic field readout gradient as usual. Instead of a phase-encoding position along the second direction, it is labeled by the time that the echo is received from the line of spins at a fixed distance along it. The simplest example of this is the old method of line scanning [15]; each line is recorded as an echo, so the position of the line can be thought of as being encoded in time. However, data acquisition for the WFT and WT imaging is significantly faster than line scanning because many different distributions of spins are excited at different times during one RF pulse. The echoes of these different distributions of spins are recorded at different times during the subsequent data acquisition.

The principal innovation in these methods is the use of a rapid succession of slice-selective RF pulses in the plane of the image. This "sweeping" RF pulse is comprised of subpulses concatenated end to end over the time of the pulse. The consecutive subpulses excite adjacent strips of spins within the slice. The echo produced by each strip, or window, of spins occurs at a different time during the data acquisition; the strip of spins contributing signal appears to move across the slice during data acquisition. These techniques can reconstruct images from data taken in a few echoes. In particular, single echo imaging is possible.

The discussion is organized as follows. We begin with a list of the requisite facts from the theory of joint timefrequency representations of time domain signals. This provides the association of a two-dimensional distribution with a one-dimensional signal, which we need to discuss our model of the signal acquisition process in MR. This is followed by some of the details of implementation in the particular cases of the windowed Fourier transform and the wavelet transform. The next subsection gives an analysis of the speed of this process. Finally, conclusions are presented.

The cost of longer imaging time and greater bandwidth requirements motivates the use of the orthogonal wavelet transforms, whose point spread function is a delta impulse. These will be discussed in the next subsection. As a final note, the observant reader has already noted that p" is a sheared version of p . This effect is easily undone, and does not really pose much of a problem.

In reality, of course, there is always a great deal of noise to contend with, and the effect of the sinc is to limit the number of strips we can acquire in a given echo. For images which require many strips, we need to acquire the data in several echoes, with several strips per echo. Since we only excite those strips we wish to hear in each given echo, the next block of strips is ready for excitation almost immediately thereafter. Thus, the multiple echo acquisition should not be appreciably slower than the single echo acquisition of a given image, and offers better signal-to-noise characteristics. The multiple echo approach also has the effect of decreasing the length of the individual echoes, which is necessary for T, weighted imaging anyway.

We are currently investigating techniques to extend the number of strips which can be acquired in a single echo, by causing the phase variation in the x direction of each strip to go to zero at the echo time of that strip. This appears to be a rather complicated procedure.

Other considerations are spatial resolution and pulse length, which depend on the gradient strength and the shape of the RF pulse. The shape in time of the RF subpulses determines how swiftly the signal from a strip of spins rephases and dephases and therefore the length of the data collection; the width of the Fourier transform of the subpulses determines the spatial resolution in the direction of the sweeping RF pulse. Both cannot be arbitrarily small for a single RF pulse. For pulse shapes such as sinc, the power drops off very slowly. The Gaussian is a better choice. Another good choice is the prolate spheroidal wave function [47].

The pulse sequence which is simplest to think about is pictured in Fig. 21 below. It consists of a sweeping 90" RF pulse followed by a sweeping 180" RF pulse. This sequence produces a projection image. The time required to generate an image is three and a half times the length of the sweeping RF pulse T,. The first strips to be excited are the first strips to rephase.

The sequence above can be made slice-selective by replacing the sweeping 180" RF pulse with a slice-selective 180" RF pulse. See Fig. 22. The rephasing order for the strips would then be reversed; the first strip excited would be the last strip rephased. The variation in echo time in such a sequence is probably prohibitive. The sequence shown below uses a second nonselective 180" RF pulse to reverse the rephasing order again so the first strip excited is the first strip rephased in the sampling period. The sequence can be made to limit the field of view (FOV) in the readout direction by making the nonselective 180" RF pulse into a selective pulse in the readout direction, x in this paper. In this way, it is possible to limit the field of view in both directions in a slice-selective sequence. Limiting the FOV reduces the requirements on the gradients and the length of the sweeping RF pulses.

div.head: F. Discussion
div.p: In this section, we have described two phase space transform based imaging techniques for MR. These techniques can be implemented to produce projection images or singleslice images in as little as a single echo. Both techniques make use of a sweeping RF pulse. These pulses replace the phase-encoding repetitions in 2D Fourier transform imaging.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: We have sketched two new approaches to magnetic resonance imaging which apply wavelet transforms. In each case, the use of wavelets offers certain advantages over the traditional Fourier transform based imaging.

The first technique, direct wavelet encoding, replaces phase encoding with wavelet encoding of one of the axes of an image in a spin echo acquisition scheme. The localization properties of wavelets allow one to schedule the excitations of spin bands at various scales in such a way as to permit the acquisition of single-slice T2 weighted images in times which are short relative to current methods. Benefits of this technique include reduction of motion artifacts and Gibbs ringing. On the other hand, signal-to-noise ratios are lower than in Fourier imaging.

Our current work in direct wavelet encoding centers on the creation of excitation schedules tailored to particular wavelet bases and to particular applications. For instance, one would like to trade speed for higher signal-to-noise ratios in some instances. In other cases, T, weighting may mandate a slower but more uniform schedule. We are also investigating multidimensional versions of these schemes. These variations all feature the resistance to motion artifacts. We feel this may find application in the field of angiography, for example.
It is now part of the lore of wavelets that their use enables one to zoom in on features of interest. This intriguing notion has encouraged us to investigate adaptive imaging schemes.

To date, we have encoded all parts of the image at all scales, but in many applications this is not needed. In adaptive imaging, one pursues higher resolution only in those regions of the image where certain features have already been found at the coarser scales.

The second method presented is a technique for potentially "instant" imaging. Image acquisition is modeled as an inverse wavelet transform of the spin density in the region in question. Signal acquisition takes place in as little as one echo after excitation by radio frequency (RF) pulses designed to excite a moving band of spins across the slice. This replaces phase-encoding gradients; no fast pulsed gradients are required as in echo planar imaging.

Noise filtering, edge enhancement, and efficient digital transmission and storage of the images may benefit from wavelet techniques. In addition, other modes of image acquisition may be possible. To date, we have not considered tomographic reconstruction in MRI or elsewhere, but the recent work of others [24] suggests that wavelets may be applicable in this setting as well.
